Sub-issue: Account status incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX  is reporting that I was late on my payments for 30-60 days but I have proof payment was made in advance for the months they are claiming, payment was not received. I contacted them over the phone and they informed me they can not do anything about it or make changes since it is already being reported. 

I have written to Experian, XXXX and XXXX, for the past seven ( 7 ) months, regarding the inaccurate information they are reporting, on behalf of XXXX XXXX about my payment history. The three bureaus are reporting my payment history as Current, was past due 60 days OR Paid or paying as agreed but reflects the inaccurate missing payments, still, under section two-years payment history.

I have sent out over three letters asking to validate debt and providing letters with proof of missed payments but nothing has been resolved. This is effecting everything from buying a home to my health. I really would like to get this resolved. My account is closed and XXXX XXXX  has sent me checks because I overpaid the account. 

I received a statement from XXXX XXXX  for XX/XX/year>XXXX  with a statement balance {$380.00} that was due XX/XX/year>. A payment was made on XX/XX/year> for an amount of XXXX. Payment was processed and accepted. 

My XX/XX/year>XXXX  statement had a balance of - {$37.00}. They may be reporting I missed a payment because I did not have a balance to pay but I should not have a low score because I paid my bill balance. Look forward to this being rectify.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute of inaccurate information on my credit report Account Number : XXXX Credit Bureau : EXPERIAN Account Type : Credit Card Dear Sir/Madam In accordance with my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA, 15 U.S.C. 1681 ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA, 15 U.S.C. 1601 ), I am formally disputing inaccurate and unverifiable information related to my account with [ creditor name, e.g., XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ], which has been marked as " charge-off. '' After reviewing my credit report, I have found the following significant discrepancies between the credit bureaus XXXX, Experian, and XXXX : XXXX : Highest reported balance : {$2500.00} Current balance owed : {$2300.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' Experian : Highest reported balance : {$0.00} Current balance owed : {$2300.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' The account was closed due to inactivity. 

XXXX : Highest reported balance : {$2300.00} Current balance owed : {$2300.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off, '' with the balance reported as a " loss by the creditor. '' These discrepancies show serious inconsistencies, particularly regarding the reported balances and the reasons for the account closure. Experian states that the account was closed due to inactivity, while XXXX indicates that the balance was reported as a loss. XXXX reports a higher balance than the other bureaus. These inconsistencies violate the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ), which requires credit agencies to maintain maximum possible accuracy in their reports.

Additionally, under the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA, 15 U.S.C. 1601 ), I am entitled to clear and accurate information about my credit obligations and payment history. The discrepancies noted affect the truthfulness and clarity of the information regarding my account.

I request that, in compliance with FCRA and TILA, you investigate this dispute and immediately remove the inaccurate information, including the " charge-off, '' from my credit report. The differences between the credit bureaus clearly show the inaccuracy of the reported information. Please send me the results of your investigation and a corrected report as soon as possible. 

I have attached copies of my credit reports highlighting the mentioned discrepancies for your reference. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your timely response.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative: This notice is to inform you that you are unlawfully reporting unauthorized inquiries on my consumer reports. I have not initiated any transaction with these companies that have been listed as inquiries. Furthermore, I do not have an account as defined under 15 U.S.C. 1693a ( 2 ) with these inquiries for review or collection. Pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1681n ( a ), Any person who knowingly and willfully obtains information on a consumer from a consumer reporting agency under false pretenses shall be fined under Title 18, imprisoned for not more than 2 years, or both. By willfully violating the FCRA, I am willing to settle your civil liability damages I have suffered as a result of your violation for {$1000.00} pursuant to FCRA 616 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) [ 15 U.S.C. 1681n ]. Should you fail or refuse to settle the matter by tendering payment in the amount of {$1000.00} within ten ( 10 ) calendar days of receipt of this notice and demand, I will seek actual damages which are greater than {$1000.00}. Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate information reported on my credit report concerning a charge-off. Below are the details of the account in question : Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX Date of Charge-Off : XX/XX/2020 It has come to my attention that this charge-off is being reported repeatedly monthly, which is incorrect. According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), negative information such as a charge-off should be reported only once, reflecting the date it was charged off. 
Under the FCRA, credit reporting agencies are required to ensure the accuracy of the information they provide ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ). The continuous monthly reporting of this charge-off misrepresents my payment history and negatively impacts my credit score.

Furthermore, the statute of limitations for reporting a charge-off is seven years from the date of the initial delinquency that led to the charge-off ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) ).

Repeatedly reporting this charge-off as a new event each month does not reflect the statute of limitations and is therefore improper. 
I request an immediate investigation into this matter and the correction of my credit report by removing the repeated entries of the charge-off from my payment history. Please update my credit report accordingly and provide written confirmation of these corrections. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Investigation took more than 30 days
Consumer complaint narrative: I have already sent a letter addressing the inaccuracies and unknown items on my credit report, but unfortunately, I have not received any response even after 30 days. It feels like I'm being taken advantage of and my disputes are being ignored. According to Section 611 ( a ), if these items are not investigated within 30 days, they should be promptly removed from my credit report. Since it has been over 30 days, I expect these accounts to be updated immediately. If not, I will have no choice but to pursue legal action due to the stress this situation has caused me. Additionally, my information was also affected by the Equifax, XXXX, and XXXX data breach, which raises concerns about the security of my personal data.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute of inaccurate information on my credit report Account Number : XXXX Credit Bureau : Transunion Account Type : Credit Card Dear Sir/Madam In accordance with my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA, 15 U.S.C. 1681 ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA, 15 U.S.C. 1601 ), I am formally disputing inaccurate and unverifiable information related to my account with [ creditor name, e.g., XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ], which has been marked as " charge-off. '' After reviewing my credit report, I have found the following significant discrepancies between the credit bureaus TransUnion, XXXX, and XXXX : TransUnion : Highest reported balance : {$2500.00} Current balance owed : {$2300.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' XXXX : Highest reported balance : {$0.00} Current balance owed : {$2300.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' The account was closed due to inactivity. 

XXXX : Highest reported balance : {$2300.00} Current balance owed : {$2300.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off, '' with the balance reported as a " loss by the creditor. '' These discrepancies show serious inconsistencies, particularly regarding the reported balances and the reasons for the account closure. XXXX states that the account was closed due to inactivity, while XXXX indicates that the balance was reported as a loss. TransUnion reports a higher balance than the other bureaus. These inconsistencies violate the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ), which requires credit agencies to maintain maximum possible accuracy in their reports.

Additionally, under the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA, 15 U.S.C. 1601 ), I am entitled to clear and accurate information about my credit obligations and payment history. The discrepancies noted affect the truthfulness and clarity of the information regarding my account. 

I request that, in compliance with FCRA and TILA, you investigate this dispute and immediately remove the inaccurate information, including the " charge-off, '' from my credit report. The differences between the credit bureaus clearly show the inaccuracy of the reported information. Please send me the results of your investigation and a corrected report as soon as possible. 

I have attached copies of my credit reports highlighting the mentioned discrepancies for your reference. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your timely response.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Problem with personal statement of dispute
Consumer complaint narrative:
Complaint Details : 1. Description of the Issue : On XX/XX/year>XXXX XXXX XXXX submitted a letter to me, XXXX XXXX, stating that my auto loan was paid off. During this period, the XXXX XXXX  for the vehicle was released by XXXX XXXX and sent to me via mail, further confirming that the loan was settled. 

However, on XX/XX/year>, I discovered that XXXX XXXX had reported my account as past due and delinquent on my credit report. I immediately contacted XXXX XXXX to resolve this discrepancy. During our discussions, XXXX XXXX admitted that they had mistakenly sent the letter on XX/XX/year>, incorrectly stating that the loan was paid off, and also released the vehicle title to me in error. Despite this admission, XXXX XXXX failed to inform me of any remaining balance prior to damaging my credit report. 

2. Steps Taken to Resolve the Issue : I attempted to negotiate with XXXX XXXX and sought a resolution, making it clear that : XXXX XXXX had reported the account as paid off in their letter. 
XXXX XXXX released the title to the auto, reinforcing the statement that the loan was settled. 
XXXX XXXX never contacted me by any means to address their mistake or to notify me of any outstanding balance before tarnishing my credit report. 
I was more than willing to pay any remaining balance if one existed, as I was under the impression, based on XXXX XXXX 's communication, that the loan was fully paid off. On XX/XX/year>, I paid the remaining balance immediately upon being informed. Despite this, XXXX XXXX has refused to remove the negative reports from my credit report that were due to their admitted errors. 

3. How This Issue Has Affected Me : The inaccurate reporting by XXXX XXXX has negatively impacted my credit score, causing undue stress and financial hardship. This mistake has affected my ability to obtain credit on reasonable terms, which is unfair given that the negative report resulted solely from XXXX XXXX 's admitted errors. 
4. What I Am Requesting : I request that XXXX XXXX correct their records and immediately update all relevant credit reporting agencies to remove the negative entries associated with this account, given that these entries were made due to their mistake. I also ask for written confirmation that these corrections have been made. 

Supporting Documents : A copy of the letter from XXXX XXXX dated XX/XX/year>, confirming the loan was paid off. 
Records of communication with XXXX XXXX regarding the discrepancies and my prompt payment of the balance. 

5. Desired Resolution : I respectfully request that the CFPB investigate this matter and ensure that XXXX XXXX corrects their error by updating my credit report to accurately reflect the resolution of this account as of XX/XX/year>, and remove all negative entries that were incorrectly reported. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response and assistance in resolving this issue. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX.

The FCRA 's permissible purpose provisions are thus central to the statute 's protection of consumer privacy.

In accord with 5 U.S. Code 552a - Records maintained on individuals ( b ) Conditions of Disclosure.No agency shall disclose any record which is contained in a system of records by any means of communication to any person, or to another agency, except pursuant to a written request by, or with the prior written consent of, the individual to whom the record pertains, unless disclosure of the record would be.

15 U.S. Code 1681- Congressional findings and statement of purpose ( 1 ) The banking system is dependent upon fair and accurate credit reporting. Inaccurate credit reports directly impair the efficiency of the banking system, and unfair credit reporting methods undermine the public confidence which is essential to the continued functioning of the banking system.

( 3 ) Consumer reporting agencies have assumed a vital role in assembling and evaluating consumer credit and other information on consumers.

( 4 ) There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy.

15 U.S. Code 1681a - Definitions ; rules of construction ( d ) Consumer Report.

( 1 ) In general.The term consumer report means any written, oral, or other communication of any information by a consumer reporting agency bearing on a consumers credit worthiness, credit standing, credit capacity, character, general reputation, personal characteristics, or mode of living which is used or expected to be used or collected in whole or in part for the purpose of serving as a factor in establishing the consumers eligibility for ( A ) credit or insurance to be used primarily for personal, family, or household purposes ; 12 CFR Part 1022 - Fair Credit Reporting ( Regulation V ) FCRA section 607 ( a ) requires that consumer reporting companies, among other things, must require that prospective users of consumer reports certify the purposes for which the information is sought, and certify that the information will be used for no other purpose.

Consumers suffer harm when consumer reporting agencies provide consumer reports to persons who are not authorized to receive the information or when recipients of consumer reports obtain or use such reports for purposes other than permissible purposes. These harms include the invasion of my ' privacy, as well as reputational, emotional, physical, and economic harms.

12 CFR Part 1022 - Fair Credit Reporting ( Regulation V ) permissible purpose provisions to the protection of consumer privacy, the Bureau is issuing this advisory opinion to affirm that consumer reporting agencies may not provide a consumer report pursuant to FCRA section 604 ( a ) under any circumstance not expressly permitted by this section.

A consumer reporting company may not provide a consumer report under FCRA section 604 ( a ) ( 3 ) unless it has reason to believe that the user has a permissible purpose with respect to the consumer about whom the report is requested. A user 's request to a consumer reporting company for a report about a consumer does not give the consumer reporting company a reason to believe that the user has a permissible purpose to obtain a consumer report about other consumers. As explained in part I.A, Congress enacted the FCRA in part to address a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with... a respect for the consumer 's right to privacy.

FCRA section 619 imposes criminal liability on any person who knowingly and willfully obtains information on a consumer from a consumer reporting agency under false pretenses.

The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. 552a, protects individuals ' personal information from unwarranted invasions of privacy.

( g ) ( 1 ) Civil Remedies.Whenever any agency ( A ) makes a determination under subsection ( d ) ( 3 ) of this section not to amend an individuals record in accordance with his request, or fails to make such review in conformity with that subsection ; the individual may bring a civil action against the agency, and the district courts of the United States shall have jurisdiction in the matters under the provisions of this subsection.

( 4 ) In any suit brought under the provisions of subsection ( g ) ( 1 ) ( C ) or ( D ) of this section in which the court determines that the agency acted in a manner which was intentional or willful, the United States shall be liable to the individual in an amount equal to the sum of ( A ) actual damages sustained by the individual as a result of the refusal or failure, but in no case shall a person entitled to recovery receive less than the sum of {$1000.00} The enforcement of the regulations prescribed there under shell be enforced by the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

Subject : Dispute of inaccurate information on my credit report Account Number : XXXX Credit Bureau XXXX Experian Account Type : Credit Card I am writing to you under my rights according to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S.C . 1681 ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1601 ) to dispute inaccurate and unverifiable information on my credit report related to the account I hold with [ creditor name, e.g., XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ], which has been marked as a " charge-off. '' After reviewing my credit report, I have identified the following discrepancies between the credit bureaus ( XXXX, Experian, and XXXX ) : XXXX : Highest reported balance : {$2700.00} Current balance owed : {$2600.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' Experian : Highest reported balance : $ XXXX balance owed : {$2600.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' XXXX : Highest reported balance : {$2600.00} Current balance owed : {$2600.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off, '' additionally noting that the balance was " reported as a loss by the creditor. '' Furthermore, according to the Experian report, the account was closed due to inactivity, which is a significant discrepancy compared to the other bureaus that do not mention inactivity as the reason for closure. This inconsistency between the credit bureaus impacts my right to have my information reported accurately and fairly as stipulated by the FCRA under 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ), which mandates that credit bureaus maintain maximum accuracy in the information reported. 

Under the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA, 15 U.S.C. 1601 ), I am entitled to clear and accurate information regarding credit obligations and payment history, which is not being reflected in this case due to inconsistencies between the different credit bureaus. 

I request that, in accordance with the FCRA and TILA, you investigate this dispute and promptly remove the inaccurate information and the charge-off from my credit report, as the discrepancies and errors demonstrate the inaccuracy of the information being reported. Please provide me with the results of your investigation and a corrected credit report as soon as possible. 

I have attached copies of my credit report high lighting the discrepancies and the inaccurate information. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your quick response
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Subject : Dispute of Inaccurate Reporting of Late Payments To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally dispute the inaccurate reporting of late payments on my credit file associated with my account [ XXXX ]. This inaccurate information has been reported to the credit bureaus, and I am requesting an immediate correction under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). According to the FCRA, credit reporting agencies and creditors are required to report only accurate information. The specific late payments that I am disputing are listed as follows : - **Date of Late Payment : ** [ XX/XX/year> ] - and [ XX/XX/year> **Amount : ** [ {$30.00} ] These late payments are inaccurately reported and are causing undue harm to my credit score and overall financial reputation. Please note that under the FCRA, you are required to respond to this dispute within 15 days. I also request that any updates to my credit file resulting from this dispute be communicated to me in writing.

According to 15 USC 1666b, A creditor may not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless the creditor has adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required by section 1637 ( b ) of this title is mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the payment due date. If an open end consumer credit plan provides a time period within which an obligor may repay any portion of the credit extended without incurring an additional finance charge, such additional finance charge may not be imposed with respect to such portion of the credit extended for the billing cycle of which such period is a part, unless a statement which includes the amount upon which the finance charge for the period is based was mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the date specified in the statement by which payment must be made in order to avoid imposition of that finance charge.

16 CFR 313, also known as the Privacy of Consumer Financial Information rule, is a federal regulation that implements the privacy provisions of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ). It governs how financial institutions collect, use, and share consumers ' personal financial information. The rule requires institutions to provide privacy notices to customers, explaining how their data will be handled, and allows consumers to opt out of having their information shared with non-affiliated third parties.

According to 15 USC 1692b, except as provided in section 1692b of this title, without the prior consent of the consumer given directly to the debt collector, or the express permission of a court of competent jurisdiction, or as reasonably necessary to effectuate a post-judgment judicial remedy, a debt collector may not communicate, in connection with the collection of any debt, with any person other than the consumer, his attorney, a consumer reporting agency if otherwise permitted by law, the creditor, the attorney of the creditor, or the attorney of the debt collector. I expect that you will investigate this matter promptly and correct the inaccuracies on my credit report. Failure to comply with this request may result in further actions. Please confirm in writing that these inaccuracies have been corrected or provide a detailed explanation if you believe the information is correct. Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your swift resolution.

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX  BENEFICIARY

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have written dispute letters three different times, to each credit bureau, and each time they reply with a new credit report stating that the account with XXXX has been Verified as accurate and updated. 
Re : Formal Dispute Under FCRA 15 U.S.C. 1681 Section 602, Section 604, and 15 U.S.C. 1666b This dispute is made under 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( Fair Credit Reporting Act ), specifically Sections 602 and 604, as well as 15 U.S.C. 1666b ( Fair Credit Billing Act - Crediting of Payments ).

Basis for Dispute : 1. Violation of 15 U.S.C. 1681 Section 602 : Section 602 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act establishes the need for credit reporting agencies to maintain accurate and fair credit reporting practices. The disputed information on my credit report is inaccurate and does not reflect the actual status of my account. This misinformation is damaging to my credit profile and violates the standards of accuracy required by law.

2. Violation of 15 U.S.C. 1681 Section 604 : Section 604 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act regulates the permissible purposes for which a consumer report can be accessed. If this dispute involves unauthorized credit inquiries, these inquiries were not made with my consent or for a permissible purpose under the FCRA. These inquiries should not have been included on my credit report.

3. Violation of 15 U.S.C. 1666b ( Fair Credit Billing Act - Crediting of Payments ) : Under 15 U.S.C. 1666b, payments must be credited to an account on the date of receipt. The payment listed on my account was not credited promptly, resulting in [ e.g., a late fee, increased interest, or a negative impact on my credit score ]. This delay is in violation of the Fair Credit Billing Act.

4. PAANL ( Principle of Accuracy and Non-Discrimination in Lending ) : The Principle of Accuracy and Non-Discrimination in Lending emphasizes that all information reported on consumer credit reports must be both accurate and free from bias or discrimination. The inaccurate or mishandled information in question violates these principles, potentially leading to unfair lending practices against me.

Eradicate any and all of these following unproven genuine, FCRA compliant, and or applicable standards of reporting of which you are undoubtedly mandated in your reporting obligation ( XXXX ) to obey without default or deficiency of any sort. 

The FCRA 's permissible purpose provisions are thus central to the statute 's protection of consumer privacy. 

In accord with 5 U.S. Code 552a - Records maintained on individuals ( b ) Conditions of Disclosure.No agency shall disclose any record which is contained in a system of records by any means of communication to any person, or to another agency, except pursuant to a written request by, or with the prior written consent of, the individual to whom the record pertains, unless disclosure of the record would be. 

15 U.S. Code 1681- Congressional findings and statement of purpose ( 1 ) The banking system is dependent upon fair and accurate credit reporting. Inaccurate credit reports directly impair the efficiency of the banking system, and unfair credit reporting methods undermine the public confidence which is essential to the continued functioning of the banking system. 

( XXXX ) Consumer reporting agencies have assumed a vital role in assembling and evaluating consumer credit and other information on consumers. 

( XXXX ) There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. 

XXXX5 U.S. Code 1681a - Definitions ; rules of construction ( d ) Consumer Report. 

( XXXX ) In general.The term consumer report means any written, oral, or other communication of any information by a consumer reporting agency bearing on a consumers credit worthiness, credit standing, credit capacity, character, general reputation, personal characteristics, or mode of living which is used or expected to be used or collected in whole or in part for the purpose of serving as a factor in establishing the consumers eligibility for ( A ) credit or insurance to be used primarily for personal, family, or household purposes ; 12 CFR Part 1022 - Fair Credit Reporting ( Regulation V ) FCRA section 607 ( a ) requires that consumer reporting companies, among other things, must require that prospective users of consumer reports certify the purposes for which the information is sought, and certify that the information will be used for no other purpose. 

Consumers suffer harm when consumer reporting agencies provide consumer reports to persons who are not authorized to receive the information or when recipients of consumer reports obtain or use such reports for purposes other than permissible purposes. These harms include the invasion of my ' privacy, as well as reputational, emotional, physical, and economic harms. 

12 CFR Part 1022 - Fair Credit Reporting ( Regulation V ) permissible purpose provisions to the protection of consumer privacy, the Bureau is issuing this advisory opinion to affirm that consumer reporting agencies may not provide a consumer report pursuant to FCRA section 604 ( a ) under any circumstance not expressly permitted by this section. 

A consumer reporting company may not provide a consumer report under FCRA section 604 ( a ) ( 3 ) unless it has reason to believe that the user has a permissible purpose with respect to the consumer about whom the report is requested. A user 's request to a consumer reporting company for a report about a consumer does not give the consumer reporting company a reason to believe that the user has a permissible purpose to obtain a consumer report about other consumers. As explained in part I.A, Congress enacted the FCRA in part to address a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with... a respect for the consumer 's right to privacy.

FCRA section 619 imposes criminal liability on any person who knowingly and willfully obtains information on a consumer from a consumer reporting agency under false pretenses. 

The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. 552a, protects individuals ' personal information from unwarranted invasions of privacy. 

( g ) ( 1 ) Civil Remedies.Whenever any agency ( A ) makes a determination under subsection ( d ) ( 3 ) of this section not to amend an individuals record in accordance with his request, or fails to make such review in conformity with that subsection ; the individual may bring a civil action against the agency, and the district courts of the United States shall have jurisdiction in the matters under the provisions of this subsection. 

( XXXX ) In any suit brought under the provisions of subsection ( g ) ( 1 ) ( C ) or ( D ) of this section in which the court determines that the agency acted in a manner which was intentional or willful, the United States shall be liable to the individual in an amount equal to the sum of ( A ) actual damages sustained by the individual as a result of the refusal or failure, but in no case shall a person entitled to recovery receive less than the sum of {$1000.00} The enforcement of the regulations prescribed there under shell be enforced by the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate information reported on my credit report concerning a charge-off. Below are the details of the account in question : Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX Date of Charge-Off : XX/XX/year> It has come to my attention that this charge-off is being reported repeatedly monthly, which is incorrect. According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), negative information such as a charge-off should be reported only once, reflecting the date it was charged off. 
Under the FCRA, credit reporting agencies are required to ensure the accuracy of the information they provide ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ). The continuous monthly reporting of this charge-off misrepresents my payment history and negatively impacts my credit score.

Furthermore, the statute of limitations for reporting a charge-off is seven years from the date of the initial delinquency that led to the charge-off ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) ).

Repeatedly reporting this charge-off as a new event each month does not reflect the statute of limitations and is therefore improper.

I request an immediate investigation into this matter and the correction of my credit report by removing the repeated entries of the charge-off from my payment history. Please update my credit report accordingly and provide written confirmation of these corrections.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

My consumer rights are protected as The UCC states ( a ) A person is not liable on an instrument unless ( i ) the person signed the instrument, or ( ii ) the person is represented by an agent or representative who signed the instrument and the signature is binding on the represented person under Section 3-402. The UCC requires that any contract for the sale of goods that is worth {$500.00} or more must be in writing and signed by the person the contract is being enforced against. Under UCC Section 3-401 ( a ) If the party does not sign, the party can not be held liable. XXXX XXXX need cease & desist, remove all derogatory marks & publishing ( s ) of account on my credit report especially with Experian credit reporting. Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute of inaccurate information on my credit report Account Number : XXXXXXXX  Credit Bureau XXXX Experian Account Type : Credit Card I am writing under my rights granted by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S.C . 1681 ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1601 ) to dispute inaccurate and unverifiable information that appears on my credit report regarding the account I hold with [ creditor name, e.g., XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ], which has been marked as a " charge-off. '' Upon reviewing my credit report, I have identified the following discrepancies between the credit bureaus ( XXXX, Experian, and XXXX ) : XXXX : Highest reported balance : {$4200.00} Current balance owed : {$4100.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' Experian : Highest reported balance : {$0.00} Current balance owed : {$4100.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' It also states that the account was closed due to inactivity. 

XXXX : Highest reported balance : $ XXXX balance owed : $ XXXX status : Closed, reported as " Charged off, '' and notes the balance was " reported as a loss by the creditor. '' These discrepancies show significant inconsistencies between the credit bureaus, particularly in regard to the high balance amounts and account closure reasons. According to Experian, the account was closed due to inactivity, while XXXX indicates it was reported as a loss by the creditor. Furthermore, XXXX provides different information about the high balance. This inconsistency violates the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ), which mandates that credit reporting agencies ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information.

Additionally, under the Truth in Lending Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1601 ), I am entitled to clear and accurate information about my credit obligations and payment history, which is currently not being accurately reflected due to these discrepancies between the credit bureaus. 


I am requesting that, in compliance with the FCRA and TILA, you investigate this dispute and remove the inaccurate information, including the charge-off, from my credit report. The conflicting data between the bureaus demonstrates the inaccuracy of the information being reported. Please provide me with the results of your investigation and a corrected credit report as soon as possible. 

I have attached copies of my credit report highlighting the discrepancies and inaccurate information for your reference. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your quick response.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute of inaccurate information on my credit report Account Number : XXXXXXXX  Credit Bureau XXXX EQUIFAX Account Type : Credit Card I am writing under my rights granted by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S.C . 1681 ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1601 ) to dispute inaccurate and unverifiable information that appears on my credit report regarding the account I hold with [ creditor name, e.g., XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ], which has been marked as a " charge-off. '' Upon reviewing my credit report, I have identified the following discrepancies between the credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, and Equifax ) : XXXX : Highest reported balance : {$4200.00} Current balance owed : {$4100.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' XXXX : Highest reported balance : {$0.00} Current balance owed : {$4100.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' It also states that the account was closed due to inactivity. 

Equifax : Highest reported balance : XXXX XXXXCurrent balance owed : XXXX XXXXPayment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off, '' and notes the balance was " reported as a loss by the creditor. '' These discrepancies show significant inconsistencies between the credit bureaus, particularly in regard to the high balance amounts and account closure reasons. According to XXXX, the account was closed due to inactivity, while Equifax indicates it was reported as a loss by the creditor. Furthermore, XXXX provides different information about the high balance. This inconsistency violates the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ), which mandates that credit reporting agencies ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information.

Additionally, under the Truth in Lending Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1601 ), I am entitled to clear and accurate information about my credit obligations and payment history, which is currently not being accurately reflected due to these discrepancies between the credit bureaus. 


I am requesting that, in compliance with the FCRA and TILA, you investigate this dispute and remove the inaccurate information, including the charge-off, from my credit report. The conflicting data between the bureaus demonstrates the inaccuracy of the information being reported. Please provide me with the results of your investigation and a corrected credit report as soon as possible. 

I have attached copies of my credit report highlighting the discrepancies and inaccurate information for your reference. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your quick response.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have sent in letters asking for a Proper reinvestigation, from previously disputed letters earlier asking for a proper debt validation and verification letter and they have only sent back a credit report stating that the debt has been verified and updated. 
This Dispute is against XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  Basis for Dispute : 1. Violation of 15 U.S.C. 1681 Section 602 : Section 602 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act establishes the need for credit reporting agencies to maintain accurate and fair credit reporting practices. The disputed information on my credit report is inaccurate and does not reflect the actual status of my account. This misinformation is damaging to my credit profile and violates the standards of accuracy required by law. 
2. Violation of 15 U.S.C. 1681 Section 604 : Section 604 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act regulates the permissible purposes for which a consumer report can be accessed. If this dispute involves unauthorized credit inquiries, these inquiries were not made with my consent or for a permissible purpose under the FCRA. These inquiries should not have been included on my credit report.

3. Violation of 15 U.S.C. 1666b ( Fair Credit Billing Act - Crediting of Payments ) : Under 15 U.S.C. 1666b, payments must be credited to an account on the date of receipt. The payment listed on my account was not credited promptly, resulting in [ e.g., a late fee, increased interest, or a negative impact on my credit score ]. This delay is in violation of the Fair Credit Billing Act.

4. PAANL ( Principle of Accuracy and Non-Discrimination in Lending ) : The Principle of Accuracy and Non-Discrimination in Lending emphasizes that all information reported on consumer credit reports must be both accurate and free from bias or discrimination. The inaccurate or mishandled information in question violates these principles, potentially leading to unfair lending practices against me.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX 
XXXX, IL XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/2024 **Subject : ** Formal Dispute of Fraudulent Account Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) **To : ** Credit Bureau Dispute Department XXXX XXXX XXXX Experian, XXXX ] [ Address of the Credit Bureau ] Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to formally dispute the inclusion of an account on my credit report that does not belong to me. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have the right to dispute any inaccurate or fraudulent information, and I request that the following account be removed from my report immediately : - **Creditor : ** XXXX XXXX XXXXAccount Number : ** XXXX - **Balance Owed : ** {$3800.00} - **Status : ** Charged-off/Bad Debt - **Closed Date : ** [ Date as per report ] XXXX XXXX XXXX  Violation of FCRA : This account does not belong to me, and I have never opened any credit account with XXXX. This is either a case of identity theft or an administrative error. Reporting this account as mine is a violation of the FCRA, as it reflects inaccurate and unverified information. I have no financial responsibility for this account. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX Action Requested : I demand that you investigate this matter immediately, remove this fraudulent account from my credit report, and provide written confirmation that the investigation has been completed and the account has been deleted. If this item is not removed, I request that you provide me with the detailed investigation report and verification of ownership for this account. 

Please note that if this account is not corrected or removed, I am prepared to file a complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and pursue legal action if necessary. 

Enclosed, you will find a copy of my credit report with the fraudulent account highlighted. I have also attached a copy of my ID and a utility bill to verify my identity and address. 

I expect a prompt response, as required by the FCRA, and look forward to receiving written confirmation of the removal of this account from my credit report. 

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 168b permissible purposes of consumer reports. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 

Account Name : XXXX Account Name : XXXX Account Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX Account Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX Account Name : XXXX XXXX ccount Name : XXXX Account Name : XXXX Account Name : XXXX Account Name : XXXX Account Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX ccount Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX Account Name : XXXX XXXXXXXX Account Name : XXXX Account Name : XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX Account Name : XXXXXXXX XXXX  XXXX Account Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX Account Name : XXXX Account Number : XXXX Account Name : XXXX XXXXXXXX Account Number : XXXX Account Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX Account Name : XXXX Account Number : XXXX Account Name : XXXX Account Number : XXXX Account Name : XXXXXXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX has violated my rights. On a list of inquiries : 15 U.S.C. 1681b - Permissible Purposes of Consumer Reports : This section outlines that consumer reports can only be furnished under specific conditions. My rights to privacy and confidentiality have been violated as my report was accessed or shared without permissible purpose. 

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) - Responsibilities of Furnishers of Information : This statute prohibits the furnishing of any information to a consumer reporting agency that is known to be inaccurate or has not been verified. [ Name of Furnisher/Creditor ] has furnished information that is either inaccurate or unverifiable.

15 U.S.C. 1681 Section 602 ( a ) ( 4 ) - Right to Privacy : The statute emphasizes the need for consumer reporting agencies to handle consumer information with fairness, impartiality, and respect for the consumer 's right to privacy. This has not been upheld in my case.

15 U.S.C. 1681 Section 604 ( a ) ( 2 ) - Requirement for Written Consent : This section specifies that a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a consumer report without the consumer 's written instruction. I did not provide written consent for the inquiry or account listed.

15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) - Prohibition of Obsolete Information : This section prohibits the reporting of adverse information older than seven years ( except for records of convictions ). The report in question contains outdated or irrelevant information.

Below are the details of the account in question : Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX Date of Charge-Off : XX/XX/2020 It has come to my attention that this charge-off is being reported repeatedly monthly, which is incorrect. According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), negative information such as a charge-off should be reported only once, reflecting the date it was charged off. 
Under the FCRA, credit reporting agencies are required to ensure the accuracy of the information they provide ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ). The continuous monthly reporting of this charge-off misrepresents my payment history and negatively impacts my credit score.

Furthermore, the statute of limitations for reporting a charge-off is seven years from the date of the initial delinque
ncy that led to the charge-off ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) ).

Repeatedly reporting this charge-off as a new event each month does not reflect the statute of limitations and is therefore improper.

I request an immediate investigation into this matter and the correction of my credit report by removing the repeated entries of the charge-off from my payment history. Please update my credit report accordingly and provide written confirmation of these corrections. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/XXXX SUBJECT : DISPUTE for DELETION of Unauthorized/Inaccurate Credit Inquires. 

Dear XXXX  Dispute Department, I am writing to formally dispute the following unauthorized or inaccurate inquires listed on my credit report. I have reviewed my credit report and found these inquiries were made without my consent or are inaccurate. The details of the inquires in question are as follows : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/XXXX According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, U.S. Code 1681 e ( b ) ACCURACY OF REPORT, & 15 U.S. CODE 1681 i ( 5 ) TREATMENT OF INACCURATE OR UNVERIFIABLE INFORMATION ( A ). 

According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). ONLY authorized inquires should appear on a consumers credit report. I have not applied for credit with the companies listed above, nor have I authorized these inquiries. Therefore, I am requesting that these inquires be DELETED FROM MY CREDIT REPORT. 

Enclosed with this letter are copies of my identification and a recent utility bill to verify my identity. I would appreciate your prompt attention to this matter and kindly request a written conformation once these inquires have been DELETED from my credit report. 

I look forward to your timely response within the 30 day period allowed by the FCRA. 

Thank you for your cooperation. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Sub-issue: Public record information inaccurate
Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/2024 XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXXXXXX Subject : Formal Request for Re-investigation and Removal of Incorrect Bankruptcy Listing on Credit Report I am writing to follow up on my previous complaint regarding the inaccurate reporting of a bankruptcy on my credit report by [ EQUIFAX ). Despite being verified, the bankruptcy entry remains a clear and direct violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). I urge a thorough re-investigation and immediate removal of this incorrect entry.

US BANKRUPTCY COURT Account Number : XXXX XXXX. Persistent Inaccuracy Despite Verification : The bankruptcy entry on my credit report is inaccurate. Despite my previous complaint and the so-called verification process, this error persists. This not only causes substantial harm to my financial status but also undermines my rights under the FCRA.

2. Re-Evaluation of Privacy Rights Under FCRA : Under 15 U.S. Code 1681 ( 4 ), I am entitled to privacy and accuracy in my credit reporting. Re-reporting and verifying flawed information without thorough investigation contravene this statutory protection.

3. Questionable Permissible Purpose : According to 15 U.S. Code 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ), consumer reporting agencies must have a verifiable permissible purpose to disclose my credit information. The maintenance and dissemination of inaccurate bankruptcy information do not meet this requirement and imply a serious oversight in due diligence.

4. Inadequate Re-investigation Process : The current verification does not align with the requirements of 15 U.S. Code S 1681 ( a ), which mandates a comprehensive and meaningful re-investigation of disputed information. The inadequate and superficial verification process has perpetuated this critical error on my credit report.

The persistence of this erroneous bankruptcy entry on my credit report despite prior verification is unacceptable and a clear violation of FCRA. I trust that the CFPB will prioritize this follow-up complaint, enforce compliance with FCRA regulations , and guarantee a swift and fair resolution.

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response and resolution. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently reviewed my credit profile and noticed inaccuracies and false accusations and fraudulent accounts. I am formally requesting that these be investigated properly with immediacy. This is my second time asking these XXXX XXXX XXXX to remove these collections : XXXX XXXX XXXX, Original Creditor Name XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, Original Creditor Name XXXX XXXX XXXX Both of these charge offs have already been paid off in full by me as well as when the original creditor sold my information and filed tax without seding me a copy of the XXXX which is required by law. 
This agency is in violation of 15 USC 1692g. They were to notify me of this in writing 5 days prior, I was not notified. As the original creditor, only I can validate this debt. I do not validate this debt. The reporting of these account ( s ) is/are violations of 15 USC 1681 , and the Fair Credit Reporting Act [ 15 USC 1681 ( a ) ( 2 ) ( B ) ] : ( 2 ) EXCLUSIONS. They were to notify me of this in writing 5 days prior, I was never notified as the original creditor, only I can validate this paid debt. Therefore, the following accounts must be deleted from my reports immediately. In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) the following accounts, they have violated my rights 15USC 1681-602A states I have the right to privacy ,15USC 1681-604A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish an account without my written consent and instructions. I am not liable for this collection they have not provided me with the original contract as I have requested several times. 15 USC 1681 ( a ) ( 2 ) ( i ) states transactions and experiences between the consumer and the person making the report are not included in the " consumer report ''. By Law, the IRS defines a charge off accounts as cancelled debt that you have to pay taxes on meaning the charge off accounts are now earned income for me the consumer. Collections & Charge offs accounts over {$600.00} reporting to my consumer report is tax fraud. By Law companies are supposed to send me the consumer a copy of the 1099 from the accounts that has been charged off written as loss. The collection is now income by IRS law states that income can not be reported as debt. Please remove this account from my report this is against the law and is considered tax fraud. The account information listed directly above is inaccurate, and I dispute the validity of each. As per the FCRA you must delete all entries to my credit file that can not be proven to be accurate. Likewise, you must provide me with your Method of Verification. You are a partial owner of the eOscar system, which has proven to be unreliable for the intended purpose of my dispute and does not constitute the legally required independent investigation that you must conduct. For clarity, the sections of the Fair Credit Reporting Act of 1970 which are referenced within this letter are : Section 604, Section 609, Section 611, and Section 623. I will assume that by the very nature of your business, I do not need to provide definitions of what is covered under each of these sections individually. The Information as Shown Below Must Be Investigated Immediately. Failure to Provide Adequate Details, Method Of Verification, Accuracy Of All Dates, Amounts, and other pertinent information will result in the immediate filing of formal complaints with the CFPB and the FTC. I reserve my right to sue you civilly in the court system, which will result in my seeking the maximum allowable penalty for each item. Should I require assistance, it will be sought through an attorney, dependent on your response to this letter. Thank you very much for your cooperation. My ID has been attached as well for verification purposes.

XXXX. Subject : Complaint Against Experian and XXXX for Refusal to Update Personal Information Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to file a formal complaint against Experian and XXXX for their refusal to update my personal information on my credit report. On XX/XX/2024, I submitted a personal information update letter to Experian, requesting the correction of my address and other personal details. This letter was accompanied by the necessary documentation, including a copy of my driver 's license, Social Security card, and a utility bill to verify my address. The document was also notarized. 
However, on XX/XX/2024, I received a response from Experian stating that my request could not be processed because I did not provide a government ID. This statement is incorrect and misleading, as I had included all required documents, including a government-issued ID, in my initial submission. 
Attached to this complaint, you will find a copy of my original personal information update letter and all supporting documents that were submitted to Experian. 
I believe that Experian 's refusal to update my information is a violation of my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically under sections 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( Procedure in case of disputed accuracy ) and 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ( Compliance procedures to ensure maximum possible accuracy ).

Experian 's failure to acknowledge and properly review the provided documentation is a direct violation of my rights under the FCRA. According to the FCRA, consumers have the right to dispute inaccurate information on their credit reports and must be provided with a fair and reasonable investigation of their dispute. By ignoring the documentation I provided, XXXX has failed to uphold their obligation to conduct a fair investigation, thereby violating my consumer rights. 
I request that the CFPB investigate this matter and ensure that Experian updates my personal information as requested. Additionally, I seek confirmation that my credit report will reflect the accurate and updated information without further delays. 
Furthermore, I demand a deletion of all personally identifiable information from my consumer credit report with the exception of :

I have repeatedly sent letters to XXXX, XXXX, and Equifax requesting the removal of old, outdated, and incorrect information from my credit reports, but they have failed to respond or take any action. This negligence is highly concerning as it affects my financial standing and could harm my reputation with future employers and creditors. 

Despite providing proof of my correct personal information and identity, including copies of my Driver License, Social Security Card, and Utility Bill, the credit reporting agencies have not made the necessary corrections. This inaccurate reporting creates a misleading image of my credit history, suggesting I have lived at multiple addresses simultaneously with different phone numbers and employers. 

I demand that XXXX, XXXX, and Equifax promptly remove all the incorrect information from my credit reports as it is damaging and misleading. Their failure to address these issues is a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, and I expect immediate action to rectify this situation to avoid any further consequences on my financial well-being.

Consumer complaint narrative:
**Yes, credit report companies can frustrate interstate commerce. ** Here 's how : 1. **Inconsistent Standards : ** Different credit reporting agencies may have varying standards for reporting and scoring credit information. This inconsistency can make it difficult for businesses operating across state lines to accurately assess creditworthiness.

2. **Data Accuracy Issues : ** Errors in credit reports can negatively impact individuals and businesses, leading to difficulties in obtaining loans, financing, or even employment. These errors can be time-consuming to correct, especially when dealing with multiple credit reporting agencies.

3. **Limited Access to Credit : ** Individuals and businesses in certain regions, particularly rural areas, may have limited access to credit due to factors like lack of local lenders or reliance on credit reporting agencies that are less familiar with their specific circumstances. 
XXXX. **Excessive Fees : ** Some credit reporting agencies charge fees for accessing credit reports or correcting errors, which can be a financial burden for individuals and businesses, especially those operating on a tight budget. 

These factors can hinder the smooth flow of goods, services, and capital across state lines, ultimately impacting the overall health of the economy. To address these issues, various regulations and initiatives have been implemented, such as the Fair Credit Reporting Act, which provides consumers with certain rights regarding their credit reports.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing this complaint today because on XX/XX/XXXX, I sent XXXX XXXX XXXX Bank a letter formally revoking any, past or present, implied written, verbal, non-written, non-verbal, or assumed right to freely report transactions and experiences on this account to my consumer report. Per the protection of my privacy via The Privacy Act of 1974.There has been no response and a continuation of reported information for the month of XX/XX/XXXX. 

Event Summary : I received a copy of my official consumer report in the month of XXXX & XXXX. After reviewing all information on the consumer report, this account showed multiple inaccuracies. I then reached out directly to the company to get some clarification on the status of my account and the information given from the furnished was not correctly conveyed across all CRAs reports. The Credit Reporting Agencies are showing inconsistencies with each other and as well as showing Account Status inconsistencies with the furnisher, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX clearly violating my rights protected under the FCRA XXXX Which, as we know is to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of my consumer report and is the ASSUMED responsibility of the CRAs. Given the sheer number of inaccuracies reported and the impact that continuing to entrust this responsibility of reporting this account, May have a negative impact on my ability to obtain credit in the future. As it is ultimately MY responsibility to ensure that my NPPI, consumer report, and reputation is properly protected and maintained. I wrote a letter on XX/XX/XXXX addressed to XXXX XXXX, giving notice of my right to opt out and instruction on reporting certain nonpublic personal information on my consumer report covered under the privacy act of XXXX. 

My intention is to maintain a working relationship with XXXX XXXX, and All CRAs. However this CAN NOT continue to be tolerated. Under no circumstances should there be this many violations on a public record. All exhibits and evidence are outlined in the attachments of this compliant. 

Thank you very much for prompt attention to this matter.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate information reported on my credit report concerning a charge-off. Below are the details of the account in question : Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX Account Number:XXXX  Date of Charge-Off : XX/XX/year> It has come to my attention that this charge-off is being reported repeatedly monthly, which is incorrect. According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), negative information such as a charge-off should be reported only once, reflecting the date it was charged off.Under the FCRA, credit reporting agencies are required to ensure the accuracy of the information they provide ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ). The continuous monthly reporting of this charge-off misrepresents my payment history and negatively impacts my credit score. Furthermore, the statute of limitations for reporting a charge-off is seven years from the date of the initial delinquency that led to the charge-off ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) ). Repeatedly reporting this charge-off as a new event each month does not reflect the statute of limitations and is therefore improper. 
I request an immediate investigation into this matter and the correction of my credit report by removing the repeated entries of the charge-off from my payment history. Please update my credit report accordingly and provide written confirmation of these corrections. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute of inaccurate information on my credit report Account Number : XXXX Credit Bureau XXXX TRASUNION Account Type : Credit Card I am writing to you under my rights according to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S.C . 1681 ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1601 ) to dispute inaccurate and unverifiable information on my credit report related to the account I hold with [ creditor name, e.g.XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ], which has been marked as a " charge-off. '' After reviewing my credit report, I have identified the following discrepancies between the credit bureaus ( TransUnion, XXXX, and XXXX ) : TransUnion : Highest reported balance : {$2700.00} Current balance owed : {$2600.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' XXXX : Highest reported balance : $ XXXX balance owed : {$2600.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' XXXX : Highest reported balance : {$2600.00} Current balance owed : {$2600.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off, '' additionally noting that the balance was " reported as a loss by the creditor. '' Furthermore, according to the XXXX report, the account was closed due to inactivity, which is a significant discrepancy compared to the other bureaus that do not mention inactivity as the reason for closure. This inconsistency between the credit bureaus impacts my right to have my information reported accurately and fairly as stipulated by the FCRA under 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ), which mandates that credit bureaus maintain maximum accuracy in the information reported. 

Under the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA, 15 U.S.C. 1601 ), I am entitled to clear and accurate information regarding credit obligations and payment history, which is not being reflected in this case due to inconsistencies between the different credit bureaus. 

I request that, in accordance with the FCRA and TILA, you investigate this dispute and promptly remove the inaccurate information and the charge-off from my credit report, as the discrepancies and errors demonstrate the inaccuracy of the information being reported. Please provide me with the results of your investigation and a corrected credit report as soon as possible. 

I have attached copies of my credit report highlighting the discrepancies and the inaccurate information. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your quick response.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate information reported on my credit report concerning a charge-off. Below are the details of the account in question : Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX Account Number:XXXX Date of Charge-Off : XX/XX/year> It has come to my attention that this charge-off is being reported repeatedly monthly, which is incorrect. According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), negative information such as a charge-off should be reported only once, reflecting the date it was charged off. 
Under the FCRA, credit reporting agencies are required to ensure the accuracy of the information they provide ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ). The continuous monthly reporting of this charge-off misrepresents my payment history and negatively impacts my credit score. Furthermore, the statute of limitations for reporting a charge-off is seven years from the date of the initial delinquency that led to the charge-off ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) ). Repeatedly reporting this charge-off as a new event each month does not reflect the statute of limitations and is therefore improper.

I request an immediate investigation into this matter and the correction of my credit report by removing the repeated entries of the charge-off from my payment history. Please update my credit report accordingly and provide written confirmation of these corrections.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute of inaccurate information on my credit report Account Number : XXXX Credit Bureau : EQUIFAX Account Type : Credit Card Dear Sir/Madam In accordance with my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA, 15 U.S.C. 1681 ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA, 15 U.S.C. 1601 ), I am formally disputing inaccurate and unverifiable information related to my account with [ creditor name, e.g., XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ], which has been marked as " charge-off. '' After reviewing my credit report, I have found the following significant discrepancies between the credit bureaus XXXX, XXXX, and Equifax : XXXX : Highest reported balance : {$2500.00} Current balance owed : {$2300.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' XXXX : Highest reported balance : {$0.00} Current balance owed : {$2300.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' The account was closed due to inactivity. 

Equifax : Highest reported balance : {$2300.00} Current balance owed : {$2300.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off, '' with the balance reported as a " loss by the creditor. '' These discrepancies show serious inconsistencies, particularly regarding the reported balances and the reasons for the account closure. XXXX states that the account was closed due to inactivity, while Equifax indicates that the balance was reported as a loss. XXXX reports a higher balance than the other bureaus. These inconsistencies violate the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ), which requires credit agencies to maintain maximum possible accuracy in their reports.

Additionally, under the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA, 15 U.S.C. 1601 ), I am entitled to clear and accurate information about my credit obligations and payment history. The discrepancies noted affect the truthfulness and clarity of the information regarding my account.

I request that, in compliance with FCRA and TILA, you investigate this dispute and immediately remove the inaccurate information, including the " charge-off, '' from my credit report. The differences between the credit bureaus clearly show the inaccuracy of the reported information. Please send me the results of your investigation and a corrected report as soon as possible. 

I have attached copies of my credit reports highlighting the mentioned discrepancies for your reference. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your timely response.

Account number XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX According to 15 USC 1681i ( 5 ) the credit bureaus have to modify or delete accounts that are not reporting accurately According to 15 USC 1681b ( 1 ) the credit bureaus dont have no written premission According to 15 USC 1681 I have the right to privacy According to 15 USC 1681s-2 A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Sub-issue: Investigation took more than 30 days
Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute of inaccurate information on my credit report Account Number : XXXX Credit Bureau XXXX TRANSUNION Account Type : Credit Card I am writing under my rights granted by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( XXXX U.S.C . 1681 ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1601 ) to dispute inaccurate and unverifiable information that appears on my credit report regarding the account I hold with [ creditor name, e.gXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ], which has been marked as a " charge-off. '' Upon reviewing my credit report, I have identified the following discrepancies between the credit bureaus ( TransUnion, XXXX, and XXXX ) : TransUnion : Highest reported balance : {$4200.00} Current balance owed : {$4100.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' XXXX : XXXX reported balance : {$0.00} Current balance owed : {$4100.00} Payment status : Closed, reported as " Charged off. '' It also states that the account was closed due to inactivity. 

XXXX : XXXX reported balance : $ XXXX balance owed : $ XXXX status : Closed, reported as " Charged off, '' and notes the balance was " reported as a loss by the creditor. '' These discrepancies show significant inconsistencies between the credit bureaus, particularly in regard to the high balance amounts and account closure reasons. According to XXXX, the account was closed due to inactivity, while XXXX indicates it was reported as a loss by the creditor. Furthermore, TransUnion provides different information about the high balance. This inconsistency violates the FCRA ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ( b ) ), which mandates that credit reporting agencies ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information. 

Additionally, under the Truth in Lending Act ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ), I am entitled to clear and accurate information about my credit obligations and payment history, which is currently not being accurately reflected due to these discrepancies between the credit bureaus. 


I am requesting that, in compliance with the FCRA and XXXX, you investigate this dispute and remove the inaccurate information, including the charge-off, from my credit report. The conflicting data between the bureaus demonstrates the inaccuracy of the information being reported. Please provide me with the results of your investigation and a corrected credit report as soon as possible. 

I have attached copies of my credit report highlighting the discrepancies and inaccurate information for your reference.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have disputed this account a few times with each credit bureau and each time they all reply within a credit report stating that this account with XXXX XXXX has been verified as accurate and updated. 
Debt Validation Request under 15 U.S.C. 1692g ( FDCPA ) Verification Request : Under my rights under 15 U.S.C. 1692g, I am requesting that you provide the following information : 1. The Amount of the Debt : A detailed accounting of the debt, including the principal, interest, fees, and any other charges that have been applied.

2. The Name of the Creditor to Whom the Debt is Currently Owed : Including the name and address of the original creditor if different from the current creditor.

3. Verification of the Debt : A copy of the judgment ( if applicable ) or other documents showing that I am indeed legally obligated to pay this debt.

4. Proof of Your Legal Right to Collect the Debt : Documentation that you are authorized to collect this debt on behalf of the creditor.

5. Complete Payment History : Showing how the amount claimed was calculated and all transactions related to the debt.

According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically sections 607 ( b ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ), 623 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) ), and 623 ( a ) ( 2 ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 2 ) ), information furnished to consumer reporting agencies must be accurate and complete. A charge-off should not be reported each month as a new charge-off ; instead, the status should reflect the original charge-off date and not be reported repeatedly as if it were a new event.

The actions being taken each month affect my credit score, credit report, and creditworthiness.
